page.title: 05The Bridge of Hebden
page.content: The oldest man-made structure in the area is probably the{bridge}in Hebden Bridge. In medieval times the bridge was built out of wood, but in 1510 it was altered and replaced by stone. In view from above there are three triangle shapes which people used to go in when pack horses were passing by. The bridge was made because there was a shallow river running all along the middle of Hebden Bridge and lots of people had difficulty crossing it. Then in 1602 and 1657 the bridge was repaired and its parapets were made higher and longer. The parapet was repaired in 1845. The Eastern arch crossed the tail race which ran all the way from Bridge Mill, which was a Manorial corn mill for the parish of Wadsworth.
